Expectation1: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation1: The client's hair is freshly washed from home and feels clean.
Situation2: An invited guest speaker has prepared a sermon and can take the pulpit if needed.
Story: I stood behind my salon chair, comb in hand, as Mrs. Rahman settled in. She smiled, “No need to wash my hair today, I just did it at home.” Her hair was soft and clean, but our salon policy—and my own sense of professionalism—said every client should have their hair washed before a cut. I glanced at the clock. In less than an hour, I was supposed to be at the mosque, delivering the Friday sermon. But today, we had a guest speaker ready to step in if I couldn’t make it. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Khutbah at 1:30.” I felt the weight of both roles pressing on me. As a hairdresser, I wanted to respect Mrs. Rahman’s wishes and save her time, but I also worried about breaking protocol. As an imam, I knew the congregation expected me to be there, but the guest speaker was prepared. My mind raced, torn between the expectations of my clients and my community, feeling the tension of wanting to do right by both.
